abstract.p: Book Eating and Drinking in France by Andy Herbach and Michael Dillon offers guide to decoding French menus; photo (S)

block.p: ''Eating and Drinking in France'' is an opinionated little compendium. Its authors, Andy Herbach and Michael Dillon, hate to eat brains and such and do their best to steer their readers away from dishes like gras-double, or tripe. But their 128-page pocket-size book (Capra Press, $8.95) is handy for travelers who might not know that in France an entree is a first course, not a main dish, or how to say ''table for two'' (''une table pour deux''), for example.

''Eating and Drinking in France'' is an opinionated little compendium. Its authors, Andy Herbach and Michael Dillon, hate to eat brains and such and do their best to steer their readers away from dishes like gras-double, or tripe. But their 128-page pocket-size book (Capra Press, $8.95) is handy for travelers who might not know that in France an entree is a first course, not a main dish, or how to say ''table for two'' (''une table pour deux''), for example.

Most of the book is a concise French menu decoder. One could nitpick at some off-base renditions, like giving flank steak as the equivalent for both bavette and onglet (onglet is hanger steak), or socca as a cornmeal cake (it's a crepe made with chickpea flour) and saying that grenouille, or frog, is pronounced gren-WE, not greh-noo-EE. But why quibble when dinner is waiting?
